headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance: Top Stories for Oct. 4, 2011

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Rangers Eliminate Rays in 4-3 Win
summary: Behind three home runs from Adrian Beltre, the Rangers ended the storybook ride for the Tampa Bay Rays with a 4-3 win at Tropicana Field to clinch their American League Division Series 3-1 and return to the ALCS for a second consecutive year.

headline: Wall Street Protest Spreads
summary: As anti-Wall Street protests spread from New York to other U.S. cities, the activists beginning their third week inside a Lower Manhattan park urged participants to dress up as 'corporate zombies' on Monday.

headline: Apple's New iPhone
summary: Apple unveiled Tuesday a new iPhone 4S smartphone, which includes new camera and processor.

headline: Nissan to Build Brazil Plant in Expansion
summary: Nissan Motor is set to disclose a plan to build a $1.5 billion plant in Brazil, and is counting on substantial growth in the country to help drive a strategy to expand its share of the global auto market.

headline: Ireland Still Faces Bailout Challenges
summary: Ireland's recovery remains tied to the country's exports, and weak consumer demand will continue to weigh on the troubled euro-area economy, the country's central bank said.

headline: Disney to Convert More Titles to 3-D
summary: Disney plans to create 3-D versions of four of its best-known animation titles over the next two years, following an unexpectedly successful run for a similar conversion of "The Lion King."

headline: Helicopter Crashes in New York's East River
summary: A helicopter with a pilot and four passengers crashed into the East River shortly after taking off Tuesday afternoon, killing one of the passengers.

headline: Chris Christie's Long Goodbye
summary: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie said he will not seek the Republican presidential nomination, ending weeks of speculation about his presidential ambitions.

headline: Stocks Rally to End Higher
summary: Stocks climbed in the final hour of trading after a report that European Union finance ministers are discussing ways to recapitalize the Continent's banks.

headline: Panetta Urges Egypt to Lift State of Emergency
summary: Defense Secretary Leon Panetta on Tuesday pressed Egyptian officials to lift the country's state of emergency before holding parliamentary elections at the end of November.

headline: Jenkins: What Financial Crisis?
summary: Politicians aren't the only ones in denial about new realities.

headline: FDA: Avastin Could Affect Fertility in Women
summary: Treatment with Roche Holding AG's cancer drug Avastin might affect fertility in some women, the Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Black Entertainment Television founder Robert Johnson on President Obama and the wealthy.

headline: Slovakia Sets Date for Euro Rescue Fund Vote
summary: Slovakia's four-party coalition government Tuesday agreed to bring forward to Oct. 11 a parliament vote on the expansion of a bailout fund, but failed to get the endorsement of all lawmakers.

headline: FDA Research Led to Listeria Discovery
summary: The recent discovery of deadly listeria contamination in bags of chopped romaine lettuce was discovered by a federal research effort started this year to gauge food-safety conditions surrounding leafy green vegetables.

headline: IPO Drought Looks Set to End Next Week
summary: The end of the two-month IPO drought in the U.S. appears near as Ubiquiti Networks is planning to price its stock offering next week and launch on the Nasdaq.

headline: Fed Taps Two Canadian Banks as Primary Dealers
summary: The Federal Reserve added two of the largest Canadian banks to an exclusive club of dealers that plays a key role in providing liquidity in the $9.5 trillion Treasury bond market while acting as the central bank's counterparty for monetary-policy operations.

headline: Apple CEO Faces First Public Test
summary: As Apple is expected to unveil its next-generation iPhone, new CEO Tim Cook faces his first public test since taking the reins from Steve Jobs.

headline: Copper Volatility Short-term Concern to CEO
summary: Chile's Codelco, sees the metal's current price volatility as a short-term concern, driven by global macroeconomic uncertainty, which threatens the timing of a bond issue.

headline: Treasurys Sink on Euro-Zone Plans
summary: A late-day surge in U.S. stocks chipped away at Treasurys, pushing prices to session lows on word that euro-zone authorities are looking into ways to recapitalize the region's financial institutions.

headline: Phone-Subsidy System Faces Overhaul
summary: Federal regulators plan to overhaul an $8 billion federal phone-subsidy system later this month, a move being closely watched by consumer groups and industry for its impact on rural-area telephone service.

headline: Labor Department Unveils Job Training Grants
summary: The fees employers pay to bring temporary workers into the U.S. will be used to train American workers for jobs, as part of a $160 million grant program to help businesses curb reliance on foreign workers for some highly skilled jobs.

headline: Euro Reverses Losses Against Dollar
summary: The euro recovered from an eight-month low against the dollar, helped by a downbeat U.S. economic assessment by Bernanke and European Central Bank President Trichet's stance against inflation.

headline: How Banks Finished in Stadium-Sponsorship Ranks
summary: The New York Mets, fourth-place finishers in the National League East, won at least one title—for its corporate stadium sponsor, Citigroup Inc. The team's home park, Citi Field, got the most bang for its naming-rights bucks, according to a study.

headline: H-P Names New Head of Networking Business
summary: Hewlett-Packard Co. named Bethany Mayer senior vice president and general manager of its networking business as the technology company continued to shuffle its management.

headline: Real Mex Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Mexican-themed casual-dining chain Real Mex Restaurants filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Tuesday with plans to look for a buyer.

headline: Hedge Funds Hit Resistance on European-Bank Trades
summary: A number of hedge funds late last month tried to reduce their exposure to European banks with Credit Suisse using derivatives, but the Swiss dealer declined to take some of their trades.

headline: Anheuser to Pour Funds Into U.S. Plants
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBevN.V. plans to invest more than $1 billion in its U.S. breweries and other facilities through 2014 to spur growth in its largest market.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are: A Peek at States' Deer Collisions
summary: While the rate of deer collisions nationwide is on the decline, drivers in West Virginia and Pennsylvania still need to keep an eye out for the road-crossing animals.

headline: Asian Shares Drop on Greek Concerns
summary: Asian shares ended lower after volatile trade, amid fresh concerns Greece may default on its debt after euro-zone finance ministers delayed the approval of a much-needed loan disbursement at a protracted meeting Monday.

headline: Gold Settles Lower
summary: Gold and silver futures extended their earlier losses as the chairman of the Federal Reserve played down the threat of inflation and the likelihood of another round of quantitative easing.

headline: Cerberus Defends Innkeepers Decision
summary: Cerberus Capital Management says it had a good reason to walk away from a $1.12 billion deal to buy Innkeepers hotels out of bankruptcy: Market turmoil has changed its expectations on those hotels' profitability.

headline: 'Underwear Bomber' Trial Opens
summary: The federal case against the so-called underwear bomber started Tuesday morning as the judge and lawyers agreed on several potential jurors who could be asked to serve by week's end.

headline: U.S. Bank Bonds Get Pelted
summary: Tuesday is delivering another punch to U.S. bank bonds in the ongoing volatility bout brought on by the European banking crisis. Risk premiums on the debt of bank and financial institutions are markedly wider across the board, many by double digits.

headline: Solar-Panel Firms' Outlook Dims
summary: Solar-panel company stocks have plunged as slowing demand and a glut of panels from Asia have squeezed margins, creating a cloud that could hang over the industry for some time.

headline: Heritage Oil Buys Early Start In Libya For $19M
summary: U.K. independent oil and gas explorer Heritage Oil PLC became the first new foreign firm to strike a deal to enter the Libyan oil sector following the war through its acquisition of a Benghazi-based oil services company.

headline: U.K. Defense Chief Cites Iran's Nuclear Risk
summary: U.K. Defense Minister Liam Fox said a nuclear-armed Iran would trigger an arms race in the Middle East, one of the world's most unstable regions.

headline: Dexia Shares Pare Losses
summary: Shares in troubled French-Belgian lender Dexia SA pared the worst of their losses as both countries' governments pledged to protect its account holders and creditors.

headline: Apple Ready to Talk iPhone on Tuesday
summary: Apple is expected to unveil Tuesday the newest version of a device that has helped bolster the company's fortunes more than any other in recent years: the iPhone.

headline: IBM to Buy Security Analytics Firm
summary: IBM agreed to buy security company Q1 Labs, which uses analytics to detect possible security breaches. Meanwhile, Intel acquired a similar security provider.

headline: New Greek Bond Deal Is Biggest Threat
summary: An overhaul of the second Greek bailout just three months after agreeing it would be a further blow to the already battered perception of the euro-zone's crisis-management abilities.

headline: UAW, Ford In Tentative Pact On National Labor Contract
summary: Ford Motor says it will add a total of 12,000 new jobs in the U.S. by the end of next year as a part of its tentative agreement with the United Auto Workers union.

headline: Japanese Yields Fall After Auction
summary: Yields on Japanese government bonds fell across the board as investors sought havens from the euro-zone crisis and a sale of 10-year debt encountered healthy demand.

headline: Maruti Suzuki Starts Output at Third Factory
summary: Maruti Suzuki India has started production at its third factory in northern India's Haryana state, which should help the auto maker cut the waiting time for its Swift hatchback, a company spokesman said.

headline: Greece: Our Finances Can Withstand Delay
summary: Greece's finance minister said the country has enough cash to continue operating until the middle of November, after euro-zone finance ministers delayed the disbursement of the next tranche of promised aid for Greece.

headline: Euro-Zone Producer Prices Drop
summary: Prices of goods leaving factories across the 17 euro-zone countries fell in August as energy costs declined.

headline: Spanish Jobless Claims Soar
summary: Spain's Labor ministry said jobless claims soared in September due to he end of the country's labor-intensive holiday season.

headline: Fire at Texas Chemical Plant
summary: A chemical plant 30 miles south of Dallas erupted in flame and burned out of control Monday, sending up a huge column of black smoke that raised concerns about toxic emissions.

headline: European Banks Try to Calm Investors
summary: European banks stepped up efforts to assure investors and analysts on their liquidity and capital positions, as the deepening euro-zone debt crisis has cast doubt on some banks' survival.

headline: Qualcomm Unveils Executive Changes
summary: Qualcomm unveiled a series of executive changes, among them moving its president into the vice chairman position and naming an executive vice president to replace him.

headline: ONGC Expects Output Growth
summary: Oil & Natural Gas Corp expects its crude oil and natural gas output to increase substantially over the next few years as it brings new fields into production, its new chairman Sudhir Vasudeva said.

headline: India Plans to Cap Fuel Subsidy at $8.15 Billion
summary: India plans to limit its fuel subsidies at 400 billion rupees ($8.15 billion) this fiscal year, scaling down its initial estimate by 50 billion rupees following easing crude oil prices and also due to its higher borrowing target, a senior finance ministry official said.

headline: Panetta Meets Israelis, Palestinians
summary: U.S. Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, trying his hand as a peacemaker, met with Israeli and Palestinian officials to try and jump-start negotiations, calling for "bold" steps by both sides.

headline: OECD Inflation Rate Rises
summary: The annual rate of inflation across developed economies picked up for the second straight month in August as food prices continued to rise sharply.

headline: Durga Puja Celebrations
summary: Durga Puja is a festival celebrated all over India, especially in the east of the country. The celebrations last for several days. Some snapshots.

headline: Champions League Twenty20
summary: Royal Challengers Bangalore prolonged their stay in the Champions League after thrashing Somerset by 51 runs. Some snapshots.

headline: Europe Credit Markets Hit As Greek Aid Delayed
summary: European financial markets took another whack after euro-zone finance ministers delayed the next loan payment to Greece.

headline: Ex-Japan Official: Euro Pessimism Overdone
summary: The euro is undervalued against both the dollar and yen, said former top Japanese currency official Makoto Utsumi, arguing that speculation about a Greek default or German abandonment of the currency has become overly pessimistic.

headline: U.K. Construction Slows
summary: Activity in the U.K.'s construction sector was all but stagnant in September as new orders fell, dragging down the pace of growth in other sub-sectors measured by an index published by Markit.

headline: Europe's Telcos Don't Need a Copper Curb
summary: European Union Commissioner Neelie Kroes is proposing new regulation to cut existing earnings unless telecommunication firms build new, faster fiber-optic networks. That seems a strange way to boost future investment.

headline: Essar Plans London IPO for Unit
summary: India's Essar group is planning to list a unit comprising its infrastructure building and ports businesses in London, two people familiar with the matter said, with one of them saying the offering planned for 2012 could raise at least $750 million.

headline: Daniel Ricciardo Woos Delhi
summary: During a Grand Prix promotional event on Saturday, Australian Formula One driver Daniel Ricciardo treated fans to the unfamiliar sight of an F1 car traveling on Rajpath road. Some snapshots.

headline: Infosys: India Software Industry to Meet 16%-18% Export Growth Aim
summary: India's software industry will be able to meet its 16%-18% export revenue growth target for this financial year through March as global businesses continue to spend on technology, Infosys Ltd. Executive co-Chairman S. Gopalakrishnan said.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: A buffalo swims in a pond, children share a meal at a makeshift shelter, Zaheer Khan receives the Arjuna Award 2011, and more.

headline: UBS Expects Profit Despite Trading Loss
summary: UBS said it will reach a modest third-quarter net profit despite $2.3 billion in losses stemming from a trading scandal and hefty restructuring charges.

headline: Hindustan Petroleum Postpones Maintenance Shutdowns
summary: Hindustan Petroleum has postponed maintenance shutdowns at its two refineries to early next year to meet high demand for petroleum products, a senior company executive said.

headline: Verlander Leads Tigers' Win in Game 3
summary: The Tigers' hot-shot pitcher Justin Verlander helped lead the team to a pivotal 5-4 victory over the Yankees in Game 3 of the AL division series, putting the Yankees into a do-or-die situation for Game 4 on Tuesday night in Detroit.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Tuesday, October 4, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Maximum Money: Is Agricultural Land a Good Investment?
summary: Indian ministers hold a bulk of their wealth in agricultural land and keep buying more. What's the fascination, and can individuals follow their lead? Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer, explores the terrain.

headline: Music Festival Rocks Kabul
summary: In Afghanistan, where music was banned for years under the austere Taliban regime, people enjoyed a one-day music festival held in Kabul.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Oct. 4, 2011

headline: Arctic Ocean Drilling Approved
summary: The Obama administration said it was moving forward with oil-drilling leases off the coast of Alaska issued by the Bush administration in 2008, a victory for oil companies.

headline: Reliable Engine of Recovery Loses Steam
summary: U.S. manufacturing managed to keep expanding in September, but weakness was noted in the euro zone and Australia.

headline: Stephens: The President of Contempt
summary: To Barack Obama, America is lovable in proportion to the love it gives him in return.

headline: Japan Panel Says Tepco Needs Restarts
summary: Ensuring the financial stability of Tokyo Electric Power will require the restart of halted nuclear reactors, said a panel advising the Japanese government on restructuring the utility.

headline: AMR Shares Swoon
summary: Shares in American Airlines parent AMR collapsed Monday on renewed fears that the nation's third-largest airline by traffic may ultimately be forced to seek bankruptcy protection in a worsening economy.

headline: Inside Sprint's Bet on iPhone
summary: As Apple prepares to release its new iPhone, the terms it has squeezed from Sprint Nextel reveal the leverage it has over telecom companies that once ran the show.

headline: A New Frontier of Frugality
summary: Retailers are coming to terms with a new reality: consumers who traded down during the recession and never came back.

headline: White House Brushed Off Solyndra Alarms
summary: White House officials dismissed concerns about Solyndra ahead of Obama's May 2010 visit to the failed solar-panel maker, according to emails.

headline: How Much Is Gold Really Worth?
summary: Skeptics are questioning gold's credentials as one of the few shelters from financial storms and investors have begun to wonder whether this is the beginning of the end for gold's spectacular surge.

headline: European Stocks Slide
summary: European stocks closed in the red with banks among the worst decliners as Greek authorities revealed that the country would be unable to meet its deficit-reduction targets this year, piling further pressure on already-fragile sentiment within the euro zone.

headline: One of New York's Anchors
summary: How long has anchorman Chuck Scarborough been on his winning streak? Here's how long: Ralph Gardner's first job out of college, in 1975, was as a desk assistant at Newscenter 4. Mr. Scarborough was already anchoring their 6 and 11 p.m. newscasts.

headline: Steering Teens Outdoors
summary: Hannah Swett wants to ensure that New York City public school students have educational and fun experiences on the water.

headline: Christie Offered Clues at Fund-Raiser
summary: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie told prominent California fund-raisers and donors as recently as last Wednesday he had no plans to seek the White House.

headline: Drilling Fee Proposed for Pennsylvania
summary: Pennsylvania Gov. Corbett proposed a fee on natural-gas drilling of as much as $160,000 per well in an effort to find a middle ground between public support for assessing drillers in the booming Marcellus Shale basin and a campaign pledge not to impose taxes.

headline: New Boys Getting Into the Rugby Action
summary: The injury that ended Dan Carter's Rugby World Cup has wreaked havoc on New Zealand's hopes. But the loss may be a bigger blow for a tournament that has been sorely lacking in star power.

headline: France Cancels Shale-Gas  Permits Over Fracking
summary: Schuepbach Energy, Total lost government permission after saying they'll use controversial technique to explore potential fields.

headline: A 5.15 ERA Meets a 4.75 ERA. It Must Be October.
summary: The pitching matchup on Tuesday between A.J. Burnett and Rick Porcello shapes up as one of the worst in postseason history.

headline: Stock Market Nears Bear Territory
summary: After turning in the worst quarter since the financial crisis, U.S. stocks started the new one by approaching the level considered a bear market.

headline: 'Boring' Sales Pace Is Solace for Manhattan Apartments
summary: Despite abundant economic uncertainty, the Manhattan co-op and condo sales have achieved a rare state of being during the third quarter: stable and boring.

headline: Loan-to-Value Ratios by State
summary: Higher loan-to-value ratios indicate states likely dealing with more underwater homeowners.

headline: Trade Pacts Set for Heated Fight
summary: Obama sent trade deals with South Korea, Colombia and Panama to Congress, capping months of tense negotiations and setting the stage for a heated if brief fight between free-trade supporters and labor unions before their likely approval.

headline: Morgan Stanley's Top Shareholder Affirms Commitment
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, in an unusual statement, said it remains committed to its "long-term strategic alliance with Morgan Stanley" despite the securities firm's sliding share price.

headline: Chinese Official Threatens Myanmar
summary: The head of a major Chinese company behind a controversial dam in Myanmar said the project's suspension by the Myanmar government last week was a surprise that could prompt legal issues.

headline: Hong Kong Shares Hit 28-Month Low
summary: The blue chip Hang Seng Index fell 4.4% to 16822.15, its lowest close since it ended at 16790 on May 15, 2009, led by Chinese financial and property shares.

headline: Ravens Defense Smothers, Outscores Jets
summary: Baltimore's D Scores Three Touchdowns and Exploits the Jets' Weak Offensive Line; Sanchez Fumbles Four Times

headline: A Jazztronaut, Exploring the Spaces in Music
summary: One of the most recorded musicians in history, Anthony Braxton also is one of the most tenacious. This week his perseverance will be celebrated with four nights of concerts at the new Roulette performance space in downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Forced to Be Frugal
summary: The "forever frugal"—shoppers who cut back and traded down during the recession and stayed that way—opt for store brands over name brands and tend to take a list to the store.

headline: The Recovering Pop Artist
summary: Feist's last album sold a million copies and risked defining her as a cheery pop star. With her latest recording, "Metals," she recaptures her career.

headline: Debut 'Twist' Purchases Fire Up Treasurys
summary: After weeks of market anticipation, the Fed began implementing "Operation Twist"—the plan to shift its Treasury holdings into longer-term U.S. debt—as U.S. government-debt prices continued to rally.

headline: Is It Time for the Jets to Enter Full-Blown Panic Mode?
summary: It looks like the Jets would be wise to panic sooner rather than later, and a simple look at the schedule shows why.

headline: The Definition of Insanity
summary: Why no one wants to repeal a program that everyone knows is a fraud.

headline: Downtown's Cloudy Office-Vacancy Outlook
summary: Manhattan's office-leasing market enjoyed a strong third quarter, but clouds are forming over downtown, where large vacancies could be looming, according to a new report.

headline: Plyler V. Doe Doesn't Apply to Universities
summary: The quotes from former presidents George H.W. Bush and Ronald Reagan ("Notable & Quotable," Sept. 29) regarding free public education for the children of illegal immigrants were rendered obsolete by the 1982 Supreme Court decision of Plyler v. Doe.

headline: Hong Kong Shares Sink 4.4%, Hitting a 28-Month Low
summary: None

headline: Protesters Draw Support From Unions
summary: The anti-Wall Street protesters camped out in a Lower Manhattan park are beginning to attract backing from some of New York's most powerful labor unions.

headline: Mosque Is Torched in Israel
summary: The burning and defacement of a mosque in northern Israel early Monday sparked a riot and heightened Israeli concerns that Jewish extremists could stoke Palestinian outrage and ignite a new uprising.

headline: 'I' Is a Window to the Soul
summary: "The Secret Life of Pronouns" shows how inconspicuous words like 'we' and 'the' betray our emotions and affect our audience's perceptions. Brian Christian reviews.
